benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: PUT /1.0/kb/bundles/{bundleId}/resume - Resume a bundle

covered: Valid Request: Multiple positive scenarios (TC01-TC04, TC18, TC24) verify successful resume behavior and 204 responses.
Query Parameters: requestedDate and pluginProperty variations are explicitly tested (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC13, TC19, TC20).
Header Validation: Required header X-Killbill-CreatedBy is tested (TC01, TC07) and optional headers X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are covered (TC04, TC12).
Non-Existing Resource: 404 behavior when no bundle exists is tested (TC05).
Invalid Path Parameter: Invalid UUID format yields 400 (TC06).
Invalid State/Error Conditions: Attempts to resume non-paused bundles (active, cancelled) covered (TC08, TC09) and invalid requestedDate/payload format covered (TC19, TC20).
Concurrency: Race condition and concurrent requests covered (TC21).
Server/Internal Errors & Dependencies: Internal error scenarios and downstream dependency issues covered (TC14, TC25).
Resilience / Retry: Transient failure and retry scenario covered (TC15).
Security: Injection and XSS attempts covered (TC16, TC17).
Boundary & Stress: Max header length and large pluginProperty volume tested (TC12, TC13).
Tolerance to extra params and legacy clients: Extra params and backward compatibility covered (TC11, TC24).
Performance: Load/performance under normal/peak load included (TC22).
Auditability: Reason/comment recorded in audit log is validated (TC04).
gaps: Content-Type / Response Headers: No explicit assertions for response Content-Type or other headers (story notes application/json output) — tests do not validate response Content-Type or any caching headers.

Response Body for Success: The story calls out “produces: application/json” but successful responses are 204 (no body); tests don’t assert the response body/headers for error responses beyond existence of an error message. More explicit schema checks for error responses are missing.
Idempotency / Duplicate Submissions: No explicit tests for idempotency or duplicate PUT requests (e.g., repeated identical requests from same client besides concurrency semantics).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting or API throttling behavior (standard GET guideline item carried over to API stability testing).
ETag / Caching Behavior: No tests for caching headers (ETag, Cache-Control) or related semantics.
Pagination-related items (if applicable): While likely not applicable for this endpoint, standard GET guideline items are unaddressed — confirm N/A for PUT endpoints.

Detailed validation error payloads: Tests assert existence of error messages but do not assert specific error codes/messages/JSON schema for 400/404/500 responses; lack of structured contract validation.
Content negotiation / Accept header: No tests verifying behavior with different Accept/Content-Type headers.

Exact pluginProperty processing outcomes: Tests assert plugin properties are "processed as expected" but there is no explicit verification of how they were stored or propagated to plugin service (observability of side effects).
Transactionality and partial failure: No explicit tests for partial failures where some subscriptions resume and others fail (atomicity/rollback semantics).
recommendations: Add assertions for response headers and content-type on both success (where applicable) and error responses; validate application/json responses for error cases per API contract.
Introduce idempotency/duplicate submission tests: repeat the same PUT and verify safe/consistent behavior (204 on repeat or defined idempotency behavior).
Add rate-limiting/throttling tests to validate behavior when many requests are sent in a short period (aligns with operational guidelines).
If the API exposes caching or ETag headers for any reason, add tests to validate Cache-Control and ETag handling; if not applicable, mark as N/A in the test plan.
Add strict validation tests for error response payloads (schema, error codes, and message text) for 400/404/500 to ensure contract stability.
Add tests for content negotiation: send differing Accept/Content-Type headers and assert consistent behavior/error semantics.
Add tests to verify observable side-effects of pluginProperty processing (e.g., events, calls to plugin service, DB records) to confirm plugin properties are actually applied.
Add transactional/partial-failure tests: simulate a scenario where one subscription resume fails and assert whether the operation is atomic (all or nothing) or partially applied per spec.
Consider adding explicit tests for id / path parameter pattern enforcement (beyond generic invalid UUID) to ensure adherence to the documented regex/pattern.
Document and mark as out-of-scope any standard guideline items that truly do not apply to this PUT endpoint (e.g., pagination), to make coverage claims explicit.
